Award.AwardTitle: Research: Predicting STEM Career Choice from Computational Indicators of Student Engagement within Middle School Mathematics Classes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study by Worcester Polytechnic Institute will ascertain how well "disengagement" of students in mathematics can be determined from math learning software and how well it predicts later outcomes of STEM learning and career advancement. The study will use with metrics automatically extracted from a computer-based math learning tool in middle school to predict STEM workforce participation after high school.

This research study will track a randomly selected sample of 1000 students who graduate from high school in 2010-2012 into college using surveys, online surveys, and on-line communities. By integrating these data with the information on when they were in middle school and were using the ASSISTment system the project can create an 8 year long longitudinal research project. They will follow the career choices of both students who go to college, and students who seek jobs instead of immediately attending college. The project will use educational data mining methods to categorize student behavior through analysis of log files recorded while students were using educational software. The investigators expect to measure disengagement and thus how student's motivation, goals, and self-efficacy towards STEM content are realized in practice with self-reports of student attitudes toward STEM careers and motivation to study science and mathematics. The researchers intend to determine whether students who had high levels of disengagement while in school, as shown by their use of computers in classes, is correlated with later life career choices, work behavior and success.

This study will result in published articles in psychological journals that are expected to add a significant step in the knowledge of how student engagement during formal school years is associated with motivations and behavior to study science and enter careers that are demanding of thought and understanding of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, there has been considerable interest in non-cognitive factors in school performance. This interest has extended beyond just the scientific community; for example, President Obama discussed them in an August 2015 speech. Barack Obama cites from his speech to students regarding research on non-cognitive factors in school performance  (August 2015).

 

There has been evidence that constructs like grit and theories of intelligence have impact on students’ long-term outcomes. This project extends these efforts to study whether student engagement and emotion during online learning also impact students’ long-term outcomes.

 

In studying these issues, we leverage a methodological revolution, called educational data mining, to utilize new measures of student engagement and emotion that are richer and finer-grained than previous approaches. As students use an online learning system for mathematics, ASSISTments, in class and as homework, every action they make in the system is tracked. We develop automated algorithms that can identify engagement and disengagement, positive emotion and negative emotions. We verify that these algorithms agree with the judgments of expert researchers, standing in the room with the students. We validate that these algorithms work for urban, rural, and suburban students, including traditionally underrepresented students of color.

 

In this longitudinal study, we connect this data, collected for the entire year among 11-13 year old students, to outcomes years later. We find that engagement and disengagement, and positive and negative emotion, during mathematics class are predictive of whether students attend college, whether they attend a selective college, and whether they major in careers involving science and mathematics in college. More specifically, we determine that student boredom, carelessness, and gaming the system (intentional misuse of online learning systems to complete problems without learning) are associated with worse long-term outcomes, while the positive emotional state of engaged concentration is associated with better outcomes.

 

These findings have been discussed in Scientific American as well as published in a range of academic journal papers and conference proceedings, and presented in dozens of keynotes and colloquium talks. It is our long-term goal to use these findings as the basis of a new approach to supporting at-risk students. To this end, we have already applied these findings in reports for school guidance counselors that can be used to identify students that are at-risk, and understand the specific factors leading a specific student to be at risk. Work is now ongoing to enhance the usability and usefulness of these reports, towards better supporting all students in succeeding academically and professionally. When completed, they will be made available for all of the over 50,000 students nationwide who use the free ASSISTments platform to learn mathematics.
